titleStmt.title: The walking statue: or, the devil in the wine-cellar. A comedy, as it was acted at the Theatre Royal in Drury-Lane.
titleStmt.author: Hill, Aaron, 1685-1750.

titleStmt.title: The walking statue: or, the devil in the wine-cellar. A comedy, as it was acted at the Theatre Royal in Drury-Lane.
titleStmt.author: Hill, Aaron, 1685-1750.

notesStmt.note: "comedy" in title is a paste-over covering the words: "farce of one act.".

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Walking Statue: OR, THE DEVIL IN THE Wine-Cellar. A COMEDY, As it was Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.

list.label: Sir Timothy Tough, an old Knight,
Leenora, his Daughter,
Sprightly, a young Gentleman in Love with Leonora,
Toby, Sprightly's Man,
Corporal Cuttum, the Statue,
Servants and Bearers.

div.head: THE Walking Statue: OR, THE DEVIL IN THE Wine-Cellar.
div.stage: SCENE, The Street before Sir Timothy's Houſe. EnterTobydiſguis'd like an ExchangeGirl with a Band box.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p:
WELL,—of all the croſs-grain'd old Fellows breathing, my Maſter's Miſtreſſes Father is one of the moſt hard to be dealt withal; and therefore 'tis for a Man of my Parts to ſucceed in an Aſſair that has baffled the Wit
of all my Fellow-Servants. I perſwaded him, before he try'd his own Skill, to make proof of mine, and I'll warrant I'll get the Letter to the Lady's Hands, if once I come near enough to touch 'em. I have a ſtrange Inclination to Woman-Hunting ever ſince I clamber'd over the Houſe-top, and got to Bed to Moll at the next Door, through the Garret-Window. Stay, this is the Houſe; let me ſee, I think I am Woman enough in the lower Parts, and I am ſure my upper won't fail me. I have Braſs enough in my Face, and Depth enough in my Conſcience to be really what I look to be—an Exchange Girl, Ifakins, I'll knock, come on't what will; I am ſure I am ſafe enough in this Dreſs, for tho' 'tis no new thing to find a Knave in Petticoats, 'tis an immodeſt and an unlawful thing to look for him there.
sp.stage: He knocks, and Sir Timothy looks out at the Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Who's at the Door?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis I, who's I? What's your Buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I would ſpeak with Madam Leonora, Sir Timothy Tough's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: In what Language would you ſpeak with her?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: In what Language? Why in good old Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good old Engllſh! I'd have you to know you muſt ſpeak good plain Engliſh, if you talk with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Is your Worſhip Sir Timothy Tough his own ſelf then?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I beg your Worſhip's pardon, I come from Mrs. Stitch in the New-Exchange, ſo pleaſe you, Sir, and have brought home a new Head for the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Wait, Maiden, you ſhall have Admittance.
sp.stage: He goes from the Window.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Rare Fortune, I faith! Well, I muſt needs ſay in my own Commendation, 'tis not every Body's Talent to manage a thing diſcreetly. What will this Maſter of mine owe me for ſo great a Service as I ſhall certainly do him? When a Man has good luck among Women, they ſay he was born under Caper-corn, I think they call it; and I ſhall go near to prove that Caper-corn my Maſter's beſt Planet. Adſme, I hear 'em opening the Door, now for it.
sp.stage: The Door opens, and enter Sir Timothy with a great Blunderbuſs, and two Servants with Guns and Buff Belts.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Bleſs my Heart, what Figures are here?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Houſwife! I ſuſpect you for a wicked Hypocritical deſigning Perſon, that has a felonious intention to corrupt the Obedience of my Daughter, and, leſt
you ſhould have more Rogues in Ambuſh, I iſſue arm'd, to defend the Honour of my Family. What are you? I ſay what are you?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! what do you mean? I never did you any harm in my Life, Sir—Oh! oh! loving Sir, have Mercy upon me dear Sir, for the ſake of my ſpotleſs Virginity.
sp.stage: Runs behind Sir Timothy, who preſent his Blunderbuſs againſt one of his own Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What are you? Speak or you die.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Slife Sir, don't ſhoot me, I'm Robin.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Adſo, a bad miſtake! I am dimſighted truly; but where is the Whore, the Bawd? I know what ſort of a Shop ſhe keeps, by hanging out the Sign of a Band-box. What do you do behind, Houſewife? your Buſineſs is with the Foreparts. Harry, Robin, preſent with me thus, and when I ſpeak the Word, give Fire.
sp.stage: They all preſent their Pieces at Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Oh dear Gentlemen, ſpare me, ſpare me, good Gentlemen, don't ſhoot me, and I'll tell you all.
sp.stage: He kneels.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: In the firſt place, as you hope to preſerve that abominable Life of yours, anſwer me the Truth, and nothing but the Truth, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: From the Exchange, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What buſineſs had you?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: The Exchange, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And what are you? Jilt, ſpeak preſently, what are you?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: The New-Exchange in the Strand Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What are you the New-Exchange? 'Slife, ſpeak ſenſe or you die, I don't think the Tone of your Voice treble enough for a Whore, and therefore you muſt be a Rogue, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: The New-Exchange indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Sirrah, tell me truly what Sex you are of, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: The Exchange, upon my Word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Is the Exchange your Sex, Rogue? Are you a Man, or a Whore, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: About the middle of the Inner Walk Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Adslife, Robin, make ready.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Oh! oh! ſpare my Life, and take my band-box, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Give it me, you Whore.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I'm no Whore, upon my Honour, Sir, I am but 'Squire Sprightly's Rogue Toby, make the worſt of me. Wou'd I were buried 6 Foot deep in my Maſter's Dunghil.
sp.stage: Aſide.
SirTim. opens the Band-box, and finds a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Let's ſee, what's here, a Letter? Oh, Rogue! here, Harry, Robin, rifle the Ribons, and ſee if there's never another Snake in the Fools Graſs. What's here, Puts on a pair of Spectacles. To the lovely Hands of the engaging Leonora—Fool, Aſs, adzooks this Fellow makes love like an Oxford Scholar. I'll open the Seal.
sp.stage: He breaks open the Letter, and while the two Fellows are fumbling in the Band-box,Toby ſteals back.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Timor adds—Wing as.
sp.stage: He runs off.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.stage: Reading.
sp.p: After many vain Endeavours to get a Letter to your Hands, the truſty Toby undertook—Oh Rogue, did you ſo—I'll—Ha! where is he?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Worſhip, I believe he got off while we were rummaging the band-box.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll rummage you, you careleſs Raſcals; I'll teach you to plunder before you have ſecur'd the Enemy, you Dogs you.
sp.stage: He beats 'em with the Blunderbuſs off the ſtage.
SCENE changes to Sprightly's Houſe. Sprightly and Toby.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Nay, Faith, Toby, I pitty thee with all my Heart; but thou may'ſt make a moral uſe of this unlucky Accident, and learn to believe thy ſelf no wiſer than other People. Go, lay aſide the Woman, and and take up the Statue; all things are now ready for the laſt Trial, and it ſhall be put in Execution this very Evening.

sp.speaker: Toby,
sp.p: Truly, Sir, if your Worſhip pleaſes, I had rather be the Carver's Man, than the Statue; for if the old Knight ſhou'd find out a Trick, my Diſguiſe wou'd be ſo heavy that I cou'd not run away, and he might chance to ſhoot me thro' the Head with his Blunderbuſs.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Piſh! Fool! you know he's ſo purblind he can ſcarce ſee.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ay, but if he can't ſee, he can feel tho'; and, Sir, if he ſhould happen to tickle my Sides, I ſhou'd burſt out a laughing, and diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: It's impoſſible he ſhou'd ſuſpect thee. I ſaw the Statue at the Stone-Cutter's, who told me, the old Gentleman expects it to be brought home every day, My painted Canvas is exactly copied from the Original, and the Pedeſtal 'tis to be plac'd on in the Hall is ſo high, that he won't be able to reach your Sides; or if he did, the Daub is ſo hard and ſo thick, 'twou'd deceive a nicer Touch than his I'll warrant thee. But are the Fellows at hand, who are to be concern'd in the management.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: They are all drinking at the next Ale-houſe, and the Gentleman who is to act the Statue inſtead of me, Sir, is a Man every Inch of him. He married a Woman who had beat ſix Husbands to death with the But-ends of their own Muskets, and in three Nights time made the wild Beaſt ſo very tame, Sir, that ſhe fawns upon him like a Spaniel Bitch when ſhe's afraid of a Kicking.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Thou haſt choſe an odd ſort of a Simile, Toby; but hark! ſome body knocks; Go, ſee who it is.
sp.stage: Toby goes out, and re-enters with Cuttum.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Worſhip, this is the Gentleman we were diſcourſing about.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: May I know your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cuttum.
sp.p: I am vulgarly known by the Name of Corporal Cuttum; I have been a Soldier from my Cradle, and a Cuckold from my Marriage-Bed, Sir: I have run thro' all the Mazes of Fortune, but cou'd ne'r lay hold of the Gypſie: I believe I'm too honeſt to be proſperous in this Age! and if I live much longer, I ſhall be too old to be knaviſh. I wou'd gladly make ſome uſe of my time, Sir; for I have lately learn'd to remember, that I come of a Race ſo much the Reverſe of my way of living hitherto, that egad—if I continue honeſt much longer, I ſhall be the only Fool of my Family!

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Cuttum, what Country are you of?

sp.speaker: Cuttum.
sp.p: Why, Sir, to tell you the plain Truth, there is no Country will own us, and we own no Country; we ſhould be French by our Air, and Spaniards by our ſteps, Sir; but a parcel of ſcoundrel Rogues about Town will needs have the Cuttums to be an Iriſh Family, ſor no other Reaſon egad, than the reach of their aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Have you no Friends in Town to apply to?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, there's a Relation of mine generally known about Town; he's a kind of a Wit, and has writ Plays; but he has an odd Humour, that makes him incapable of ſerving a Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: What Humour is that, pray?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he has been ſo fond of fathering Strangers Children, that he ſcarce knows how to look upon the Son of a poor Relation.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Cuttum, you are a merry Fellow; you know the task and the reward deſign'd you, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: My worthy Friend, Mr. Toby here, has inform'd me at large; and I am ready to prove with how much Zeal I would undertake an action of greater difficulty upon a leſs temptation.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: I aſſure you you have heard the utmoſt of your danger; come the worſt to the worſt 'tis but a beating, and that I preſume you could bear with Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Am I a Cuttum, and do you ask that Queſtion? 'ſlife, Sir! bear a beating?—Why, there's not a Branch of our Family, but has Patience enough that way ſor an informing Conſtable, Bailiff's follower, Female Tatler, or Marſhal of France, egad.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: That's well; I think all things are now in a readineſs, we'll go in, and about it preſently. But heark'e, Toby, is your diſguiſe come home yet?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Four hours ago, Sir—But now you talk of a Diſguiſe, am I to be a Jew, or a Gentile?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p:
Oh! a Jew by all means. Come along Mr. Corporal; while you are getting
ready I'll inſtruct you what to ſay to the Lady, for the ill Succeſs of my laſt Letter forbids me all Thoughts of ſending another.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well! o'my Conſcience, my Maſter is the firſt that ever went about to ſend a Meſſage by a Stone Porter!—
sp.stage: They go in.
SCENE, Sir Timothy's Houſe; Sir Tim, and Leonora.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Sbud, don't tell me of my Promiſe; ask any Stateſman in Chriſtendom, if Promiſes are Chains on a wiſe Man's Will. 'Tis true, I told the young Fool Sprightly he ſhould have you, but that was when no Body of a better Eſtate was of his Mind, Girl.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The ties of Duty, Sir, firſt led me to encourage Mr. Sprightly's Addreſſes, in obedience to your Commands; and now the ties of Honour forbid me to wrong a Man who ſo ſincerely loves me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I gave him my word, that if he could outwit me, he ſhould keep what he got, with my good Will, and a good Fortune; but alas, poor young Fool, his Birdlime is no better than Chaff, and an old Fowl is too wiſe to be taken by it. I have defeated five or ſix of his Projects already; and if he comes within the reach of my Blunderbuſs, have at him, by Sir Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are the moſt barbarous of Fathers! and have contrived this ſureſt way to make me miſerable.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Goodnow, Goodnow, pretty Turtle-Dove; how naturally it mourns the loſs of its Mate: Come, come, 'tis juſt your Sex ſhould ſhare a little in the Sorrow you beſtow, Houſewiſe. A Woman's Tears are like Showers in April, a neceſſary Ingredient to make up her natural Compoſition of Change and Inconſtancy.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Man without has brought home a great Stone Thing, that looks like the Great Turk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How! the Statue! bring him in, bring him in, Sirrah.
sp.stage: Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Sir, you are likely to talk of what I don't underſtand, and if you pleaſe I'll retire to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, no, pray ſtay, Daughter; I'll warrant you, if Sprightly was coming inſtead of the Statue, you would not be in ſuch haſte to be gone; but you Women never care much for a Man of Marble

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am all Obedience, Sir.
sp.stage: She turns her Back upon the Door, and leans penſively againſt the Hangings.

Re-enter the Servant with Toby diſguis'd like a Jew, with great Whiskers and a ſhort Cloak,
followed by four Men bearing in a Frame upon which ſtands Corporal Cuttum in the Poſture of a Statue.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Save you, Sir!—have a care, have a care, gently, gently, I ſay,—Sir, Mr. Chiſſel has ſent home your Statue, Sir, and where would you pleaſe it ſhould be ſet? Have a care, I ſay, gently, gently.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Stay, let me put on my Spectacles, and I'll tell you preſently—Humph, who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I am by Profeſſion a Statuary, by Country a Portugueſe, but brought up in England; by Quality a Foreman, alias a Journeyman, and by Religion a Jew, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A Jew! adzooks, what have you to do in a Chriſtian Country, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ha, ha, you are pleas'd to be merry, Sir! But where muſt the Statue be placed, an't pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Plac'd? Aſide. Egad I don't like this Fellow, he ſays he's a Jew, but he looks like a Philiſtin.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Set him down there, gently, gently, be careful how you place him, pray, Gentlemen—So, now he ſtands right; go—ſtay without till I come to you.
sp.stage: Exit Bearers.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Let me ſee how this Statue looks.—Ads my Life, a pretty piece of Workmanſhip truly: But pray, Friend, why did not Mr. Chiſſel come himſelf? Am I ſo bad a Cuſtomer that he muſt ſend Servants to do my Buſineſs? Nay, and Heathen Servants too!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Your Worſhip, I perceive, is a facetious old Gentleman. But my Maſter, an't pleaſe you, is ſick a preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Old Gentleman! Sirrah! Is that your Hebrew Breeding! Get out of my Houſe, you Rogue! that Levitical Face of thine ſtirs up my Indignation.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I beg your pardon heartily, if I have ſaid any thing that offends you, Sir; but pray don't be in a Paſſion for nothing; is not the Work done as you expected it?
sp.stage: All the while Sir Tim. is talking with Toby, Cuttum makes whimſical Motions from the Table to Leonora, who leans penſively, and don't obſerve him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Expected it, Sirrah! I did not expect to have the Figure to be ſent home by a Rogue of a Jew, Sirrah! Let me look all round the piece, egad, 'tis 10 to 1 but the ſuperſtitious Dog has circumcis'd my Statue.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Villain, Raſcal, what, am I to be laughed at to my Face?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you muſt excuſe me, Sir, ha, ha, ha, I vow you are the pleaſant'ſt Gentleman of your age that ever I met with.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Again at my age, Sirrah; here, Robin, Jonathan, quickly, bring me my Blunderbuſs. Sirrah, get out of my Houſe, or I'll break off a Limb of the Statue, and knock out your Brains with it.
sp.stage: He runs to pull off one of the Statue's Legs, and Cuttam kicks him down backward with the other.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: 'Slife! all's out: I'll make off while I can.
sp.stage: He runs out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Rogues! Murder! help! Dogs! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Heav'ns, Sir! what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Matter! you Baggage? Don't you ſee what's the Matter? That long bearded Rogue of a Jew has affronted me to my Face, and beat out my Teeth behind my Back. Rogues! Robin, Harry, Jonathan, what, muſt I be murder'd, and no body come in to my aſſiſtance.
sp.stage: He runs out calling the Servants.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I am glad he's gone, for my Heart ak'd plaguily when he came to pull my Leg off. 'Tis a lucky Miſtake that he thinks Toby ſtruck him; but I'll take this Opportunity to ſpeak to the Lady. Madam—Madam—
sp.stage: He leaps down, and ſtalks towards Leon. who turns, and ſhrieks at his approaching her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'ns, what's here! Ghoſts! Spirits! Devils! ah! help! help! help!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Nay, now we are all undone, and egad! if you die a Maid, 'tis no more than you deſerve for your damu'd unſeaſonable ſqueaking.
sp.stage: He runs to the Table, and with much ado gets up, and ſtands in his old Poſture; but for haſte miſtakes, and puts the wrong Leg forward.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ah me! I ſee too late this is a Trick of Sprightly's.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, and his Servants.
sp.p:
Oh! Sir! I was half frighted, but beg your
pardon for alarming you; being in a melancholy Humour, I had forgot the Statue ſtood upon the Table, and looking that way on the ſudden took it for a naked Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh! did you ſo, good Daughter! I ſee very well what you would be at; this Exceſs of your Folly betrays the Lewdneſs of your Thoughts. Let's ſee, that Raſcal Jew beat off my Spectacles—oh! here they lie—Well, I vow this is a very curious piece of Sculpture, no real Fleſh and Blood could appear more lively. If that Knave Chiſſel had not ſent it by a Jew, I could have been extreamly pleas'd with it. He views Cuttum all round, who expreſſes a great deal of Fear. But ſtay, I forgot to look whether I have not-hurt the Leg tho'—adſo! what's here? I am ſure this Limb does not ſtand as it did juſt now. Daughter, Daughter. Leon. Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Look here, is it the right Poſture or no?
sp.stage: While Sir Tim. turns to ſpeak to his Daughter, Cut. puts his Leg as it was before.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Right, Sir? Yes, pray what ails it?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ails it? 'Slife I am bewitch'd—I am ſure the Devil's either in me, or my Spectacles; why 'twas but this moment the Leg ſtood here, and now—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Death, Sir, ſtand out of my way, or you're as dead as a door-nail. Aſide. 'Slife, I'll be gone while I may; if I ſtay a quarter of an hour longer, I ſhall be pounded in a Mortar.
sp.stage: He leaps down furiouſly and runs out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hey day! is my Houſe become an enchanted Caſtle? What a plague, I ſhall be hooted at as I walk along the ſtreets if this Jeſt paſſes on me. Here follow me, ye Raſcals, I'll ſtatue the Dog, I'll warrant him.
sp.stage: He runs out with his Servants after Cuttum.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What a wretched Condition has my Folly brought me to? if I ſlip this Opportunity of eſcaping while the Houſe is in ſo great a Confuſion, I ſhall be miſerable for ever. I'll get out the back-way, and truſt fortune for the Event of my Undertaking.
sp.stage: She goes out.
SCENE changes to a Court-yard, with a Well in it. Enter Toby Frighted.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p:
Here have I crawl'd about this quarter of an hour, and can find no means to reach the Door, without being diſcover'd by ſome of the old Fellow's Maidenhead-watchers; and, if I ſtay here much longer, the danger will be equal. A Pox take Petticoats for Toby, if this be the Effect of following them. What ſhall I do?—let me think a little—adsbobs I have it, I have an old black Mask in my Pocket with Horns upon it, I'll tie it on, and creep down into yonder Well, it looks like a dry one; or if I am drown'd, 'tis a better Death than to be drubb'd to Deſtruction—I'll lie quietly all Night, and in the Morning bolt thro' the Door in my Vizor and black Waſtcoat; it may ſo happen, that
the Rogues will take me for the Devil that they ſay walks in this Neighbourhood, and give me free Paſſage—But firſt, down Cloak, that if the Well be deeper than ordinary, I may be ſure to fall ſoftly; I'll tie on the Mask when I'm ſafe at the bottom. So now for it, Neck or nothing, as the Proverb ſays.
sp.stage: He throws down his Cloak, and gets into the Well.
Re-enter Sir Timothy, and the Servants with Guns, Staves, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Who would have thought that the four Rogues who brought in that Dog of a Statue, ſhould have waited ſo cunningly to carry him off again upon occaſion? Adzooks but we maul'd them in their Retreat. Go, ye Rogues, get ye into the Cellar, and drink your ſelves drunk, as a Reward for your Valour. The Servants go out bowing. Well, after all, this Sprightly is a brave bold Fellow, and deſerves the Baggage heartily; for I never could imagine till now, that any Woman in the World was worth a Man's venturing a knock on the Pate for. My Daughter is afraid of a Reprof, and is crept ſilently into her Cloſet. I'll not diſturb her till Morning, but go write an Account of this Nights Works to her good old Grandmother in the Country.
sp.stage: He goet out.
SCENE changes to a Cellar, with a Wicket in the front Scene, and diſcovereth the Servants ſitting round a black Jack, drinking and merry.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Here, honeſt Thomas, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Prithee, what Subject ſhall we be on to Night, Politics are grown muſty, Learning is below Men of a genteel Education, and Scandal you know is taking upon us the Converſation of our Betters.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Why faith, ſince we have leave to be merry, honeſt Thomas had beſt give us a Song.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: A Match, Boys—I'll ſing you a Song of my own making.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Of thy making! What, a Footman turn Poet?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: A Footman turn Poet! ay, Sir; why not? Since the Peots have met with Footmen's Encouragement, Footmen have taken up the Poets Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: But how can a Fellow without Learning, Brother Thomas, be Maſter of that ſeeling, touching way that the Poets talk of?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Pugh, Fool, the Art of Poetry is the Gift of Nature, and 'twould be no new thing to tell the World, that there's many a Footman can touch, and move, and feel, and ſtir up the Paſſions with the beſt Poet in Chriſtendom. But liſten to the Song, Boys.
sp.stage: Here a SONG.

sp.speaker: All Ser.
sp.p: Rarely ſung, 'ſfaith Thomas.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Adzookers, he has pleas'd me ſo well, that I'll e'en make bold with a Bottle of the fine Wine my Maſter has ſet a cooling in the old Well there, and treat ye like Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Why, that's kindly done now.
sp.stage: 3 Ser. riſes, and opening the Wicket, takes out a Bottle, and holds it between him and the Light.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Let's ſee, I think I have got the right ſort, no, 'tis not;—this is the Rotgut Rheniſh—
sp.stage: While the Fellow turns to look at the Bottle, Toby, having put on the black horn'd Mask, thruſts his Head out of the Wicket, and the Servant, going to change the Bottle, ſtrikes it againſt his Forehead.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Ah! the Devil, the Devil.
sp.stage: Throws down the Bottle, and runs backward.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: 'Slife, there's the Devil in good earneſt!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Rogues, Thieves, I'll be among you ſuddenly.
sp.stage: He tumbles forward into the Cellar.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Oons, Roger, fly, the Devil's amongſt us.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Help, help! the Devil, the Devil, the Devil!
sp.stage: They beat one another down, and hurry out headlong, and Toby after 'em.
The SCENE changes to the Hall. Enter Sir Timothy with his Blunderbuſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Here, Harry, Thomas Jonathan, Rogues, Raſcals, where are you? What's
the Matter below? Hey day! what's here to do?—
sp.stage: Enter Servants running.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Help, help! the Devil!

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: The Pope, the Pope! the Devil!

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! the Devil has taken poſſeſſion of your Worſhip's Cellar.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The Devil, ye Rogues! and are ye ſuch pitiful, cowardly, unchriſtian ſoul'd Fellows, as to be afraid of the Devil. Adsbob, wou'd he had been impudent enough to have come into my preſence, I'd have Devil'd him with a—'Slife, Rogues ſtand out of my way—Help, help, help!
sp.stage: In the midſt of Sir Timothy's Speech, Toby appears at the Hall Door, and the Knight beats down his Servants, and runs out firſt; the Men follow, crying out as before.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well, I have better luck now I'm a Devil, than I had when I was a Woman; and ſome arch Wags would from thence take occaſion to ſwear that the Devil is the leaſt of the two Evils. But I have no time to be witty at preſent. I ſee the Street Door open, and will lay hold on the Opportunity.
sp.stage: He goes out.
Re-enter Sir Timothy, and the Servants, peeping.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I think the Coaſt is clear at preſent.
sp.stage: They come forwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
I'll ordain a Yearly Thankſgiving to be kept on this Day throughout
my Family, for the wonderful Deliverance. Loud knocking at the Door. Stand cloſe here, for Heav'ns ſake ſtand cloſe, for I'm afraid he's a coming again.
sp.stage: They huddle cloſe together, and ſtand gazing as in Expectation; and enter Sprightly with Leonora in a Mask, attended by Corporal Cuttum, and Toby, in his Viſor.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Deliver me, ye Pow'rs, for yonder's the Devil return'd with his whole Family.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, poon Sir Timothy, 'tis a Devil of my Breeding.
sp.stage: Pulls off Toby's Mask.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: 'Tis I, my own ſelf, in very deed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why then in very deed, Sir, I wiſh the real Devil would run away with the pretended one.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Adſme, Sir, if you wiſh your Wiſhes upon me, I'll ſnatch off my Friend the Statue's Leg here, and knock your Brains out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: to Cut. Why, were you the Dog that was turn'd into Stone, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The very ſame, at your Service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: O, Sir, Love has been Author of ſtranger Metamorphoſes, than any in Ovid.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And pray, Mr. Sprightly, what pretty Part are you to act in your turn here?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: A double one, Sir, in Conjunction with this Lady.
sp.stage: Takes off Leonora's Mask, and kneels with her to Sir Tim.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Our firſt Requeſt, Sir, is for your pardon; and our next, that you will pleaſe to ratifie our Articles of Agreement, according to the Promiſe you were pleas'd to make us.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Confuſion! Furies! Devils! Witchcraft! Rogues! Tricks! Damnation! Conjuration! and Deſtraction!
sp.stage: He raves, and ſtamps, and runs off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Come, lovely Leonora, let us follow him, and mollifie his Paſſion by Submiſſion and Entreaty; and may our Example teach the World this certain Maxim:

l.hi: Love, like the Palm-Tree, by Oppreſſion grows,
Check'd, like ſtop'd Rivers, more impetuous flows,

sp.l: And, like Antaeus, gathers ſtrength from Blows.
